entry.title: Joule Studio Goes Live: Answers to Your Top Questions
entry.content:
We’re thrilled to announce that Joule Studio is now GA, allowing you to deliver a tailored, agentic AI experience for your enterprise. As we go live today, you likely have questions about what the product is about, how to get started, and what to expect next. To make your journey easier, I have put together this FAQ blog that addresses the most common questions we have received from our early adopters and during the webinar.  Whether you are just exploring or ready to dive in, you will find your answers here! 

 

Product overview:  

Q: What is Joule Studio? 

A: Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and AI agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency. 

Q: Who is Joule Studio for? 

A: Joule Studio is designed for developers who are seeking to innovate and create intelligent, conversational experiences with Joule, SAP’s AI co-pilot.  

Q: What makes Joule Studio different in the competitive landscape?  

A: Joule Studio delivers custom Joule agents and skills that are deeply grounded in business processes and data, ensuring reliable outcomes specific to your business.  

Agents delivered through standalone AI tools do not scale well in a heterogenous environment, breaking automation flows and end user experience. Joule Studio equips customers with an open and extensible framework that connects not only SAP but also non-SAP systems and models. That enables agents and skills to scale and execute efficiently.  

Security is the top concern for any enterprise, and Joule Studio delivers that. Developers can leverage built-in security and privacy enforcement, such as data masking and data filtering, to ensure compliance with AI interactions.  

Joule Studio delivers most business focused agents and skills that together extend Joule and drive business efficiency.  

Q: What are the key capabilities of Joule Studio? 

A: SAP Build empowers customers to expand Joule’s capabilities and adapt them to diverse business needs through two key components: 

  • Custom Joule Skills: Joule Studio enables the creation of tailored, business-specific Joule skills with flexibly defined logic and third-party integrations, ensuring adaptability and maximizing value. For example, retrieving weather conditions from a third-party API or vendor risks from risk management software.  
  • Custom Joule Agents: Joule Studio supports the development of custom AI Agents, leveraging data from SAP and non-SAP sources to plan and execute complex business scenarios, and enhance decision-making processes. For example, a logistic agent that optimizes shipment delivery routes based on real time data such as weather conditions, carrier availability, and other aspects.  

 

Conceptual: 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Skills and AI agents? 

A: It is important to note the technical differences between custom Joule agents and skills. Below table summarizes it - 

 

 

Joule skills 

AI agents 

Aspects 

Are part of an advanced AI model, and can act on specific operation, by leveraging the context of the conversation 

Are autonomous, multi-tool systems that solve complex problems by selecting and executing appropriate tools dynamically 

Purpose 

Single, predefined and repetitive, atomic operations 

Multi-step, adaptive problem solving 

Complexity 

Simple operations with known inputs/outputs 

Complex, dynamic workflows 

Flexibility 

Limited to predefined actions 

Highly flexible and goal-oriented 

Integration 

Specific APIs via SAP Build actions 

Multi-tool orchestration 

Resource consumption 

Minimal resource consumption 

More resource-intense due to its use of large language models 

 

Q: Is there a list of Joule Skills available and can standard skills be customized? 

A: Standard Joule Skills can be explored in the discovery center, while custom Joule skills will be managed from the Lobby of your SAP Build tenant. In the first release, standard skills will not be customizable. 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Skills and SBPA automations?  

A: Joule Skills act as the essential wrapper for automation built within SAP Build. They expose these processes to the Joule and custom agents in a secure and structured way. If you want Joule to trigger an automation — whether it’s a workflow, a bot, or a system task — you can wrap that logic in a Joule Skill. This allows the Joule and agents to understand what it can do, when it can do it, and how to safely execute it on behalf of the user. 

Q: How do I orchestrate different skills and agents?  

A: These are triggered and orchestrated via Joule based on user intent. So, Joule might call a custom skill to report compliance of vendors or an agent for setting up interviews with a candidate based on user intent and context of conversation. 

Q: What are use cases of Joule skills and AI agents? 

A: Common use cases of Joule Skills include navigation, workflow execution, and decision assistance. Skills can help users navigate specific information or documentation; collect inputs and execute structured workflows; and enhance decision-making by providing predefined insights. 

For agents, common use cases can involve both complex tasks and enterprise-wide executions. Agents handle complex, multistep workflows that require reasoning, adaptability, and contextual awareness. Unlike deterministic automation tools, agents can dynamically adjust processes based on changing business conditions and evolving data inputs. AI agents also bridge disparate systems and business domains—facilitating automations across an enterprise, breaking operational silos, and connecting fragmented IT landscapes. 

Q: What is the difference between Joule Studio and SAP Joule for Developers? 

A: Here, we should draw a clear distinction: Joule for Developers is a collection of AI powered features designed to assist developers in their day-to-day tasks, making activities such as writing code, creating processes, and performing technical operations easier and more efficient with the help of Joule's conversational AI capabilities. 

On the other hand, Joule Studio is evolving into a distinct product within the SAP Build family, focused specifically on building conversational experiences through an agentic approach. Joule Studio is where developers accelerate innovation by creating intelligent, conversational agents that make everyday tasks easier for business users. These agents will augment the workflows and processes that run your business and enhance organizational efficiency.  

In summary, while Joule for Developers optimizes the developer experience, Joule Studio will drive a broader transformation of how work gets done, accelerate innovation and improve usability for both technical teams and business users. 

 

Deployment & Data integration:  

Q: In which regions is Joule Studio available and what version of SAP S/4HANA does it work with (public or private)? 

A: Joule Studio is globally available across US, Europe, and Australia. Please refer to link. There is no dependency on SAP S/4HANA licenses for using Joule Studio, since it is integrated within the SAP Build environment on SAP BTP. So, it works with both public and private cloud versions.   

Q: Do we need to provision the SAP Build in the same tenant as we have Joule to build Joule Skills and agents? 

A: This documentation provides the exact details for setup of Joule Studio via a booster to connect SAP Build and Joule tenants. 

Q: Is it possible to integrate Joule Studio with on premise SAP S/4HANA and is there a minimum version for SAP S/4 HANA required for that integration? 

A: Custom Joule skills and agents can call APIs and BAPIs (via Actions) and Process Automation (built in SAP Build) to interact with on premise SAP S/4HANA system. However, please note that Joule skills and agents are only triggered via Joule, which is not integrated in on premises systems, meaning you will need to get any cloud solution with Joule, for example SAP Start or Build Work Zone. 

There is no dependency on SAP S/4HANA licenses for using Joule Studio, since it is integrated within the SAP Build environment on SAP BTP. 

Q: Can Joule Agent be exposed for on premise deployment after building it on cloud?  

A: Custom Joule agents can call APIs and Process Automations to interact with on premise SAP S/4HANA system. However, please note that Joule skills and agents are only triggered via a Joule, which is not integrated in on premises systems. 

 Q: Is it possible to use data products from SAP Datasphere? 

A: Yes, if you can retrieve this data via API. 

 

Security, Compliance, and Privacy:  

Q: How is personal data protected in prompts sent to agents and LLMs? 

A: Data privacy controls, such as data masking and data filtering, are enforced through the orchestration module of AI core. 

Q: What security roles are needed for the agents to function? 

A: Joule follows the principle of propagation, and both Joule Skills and conversational AI Agents will continue to follow this principle. That means any agent or skill will act within the same security bounds as the user who is chatting with Joule has, inheriting their access and permissions as well. 

 

Availability and Getting Started: 

Q: Is Joule Studio available now? What features are currently available, and what is coming soon? 

A: As of today, developers can access Joule Studio directly from SAP Build lobby and create Joule Skills within Joule Studio. 

Custom AI Agents - General Availability is targeted for the second half of 2025. 

Q: How to get started with Joule Studio? 

A: Joule Studio is now generally available, allowing you to extend and tailor Joule with custom Joule skills. To use Joule Studio, you’ll need Joule Base (or higher) and an SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311). With these, you can build, test, and deploy custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio at no additional cost—aside from the standard execution and runtime charges for the automations, apps, and processes that Joule orchestrates. 

Q: Is SAP Business Data Cloud a prerequisite? 

A: No, SAP Business Data Cloud is not a prerequisite.  

Q: Are there any learning and training resources available to upskill on Joule Studio?  

A: Yes, we have published a learning journey and a tutorial and will release a mission as well for Joule Studio. Please look out for a resource blog in the coming days compiling all resources.   

Q: Are there guided experiences to try Joule Studio?  

A: Yes – we are working on a basic trial experience for Joule Studio which will be published in the coming weeks. There are product tour and interactive value journeys available as guided experiences.  

Q: Is Joule Studio part of the SAP BTP free trial?  

A: No, Joule Studio will not be available on the SAP BTP free trial. We are working on a basic trial and other guided experiences as indicated above.  

Q: How can partners get access to Joule Studio now – is there a test environment or special program? 

A: We plan to have a Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license ready by the end of July, with dependency on SAP Build Everything and Joule Base. Please look out for future updates. 

Q: Can partners build Joule skills & agents and publish them to a store? 

A: Not in the first release - where partners will need to develop these capabilities on the customers' tenants with the necessary configurations. For future updates, we are exploring a store for partner agents and skills. 

Q: If I already have a Build license, can I start using Joule Studio? 

A: You will need an SAP Build developer license to access Joule Studio. If you have any of the older SAP Build licenses, you will not be able to access Joule Studio seamlessly. 

Seamless migration from existing SAP Build services to this SKU is not supported for now.  As a result, some manual configuration will be required at the subaccount level. 

Subscribe to SAP Build using the build_default service plan on another subaccount and ensure that this SAP BTP subaccount includes a subscription to SAP Build Process Automation (set up documentation and mission for reference). 

Manual export and import between subaccounts are required to reuse existing SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) projects, automations, and processes. This limitation applies only to content created prior to the transition. Any new content developed within the new environment will not be affected. 

 

Final remarks: 

I hope this blog answered your questions and helped you feel more confident about getting started with Joule Studio. We’re incredibly excited about what this launch means for our customers and partners and can’t wait to see how they use it to solve unique scenarios. As always, we’re here to support you — don’t hesitate to reach out for questions, feedback, or ideas.

entry.title: Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation
entry.content:
Access Joule Studio from the SAP Build Lobby.

For modern enterprises, we know that harnessing the full potential of business data is essential to making smarter decisions and accelerating innovation. To truly deliver impact, AI agents must go beyond traditional automation – they need to plan and adapt execution based on real-time data and human input. To get the most accurate and relevant results, they need a deep understanding of your unique business data and processes.

That’s why we’re excited to announce the general availability of Joule Studio in SAP Build. With Joule Studio, developers can now start to tailor and extend SAP’s agentic AI to businesses, accelerate workflow automation, and unlock even greater value.

Joule Studio is the latest SAP Build capability where you can extend Joule’s out-of-the-box capabilities with company-specific skills and intelligent agents.

In case you missed it, see the announcement and overview of Joule Studio to understand the unique value it brings deep grounding in business processes & data, an open and extensible framework, and built-in Security & Compliance.

In this post, I’ll share more about what’s available today: custom Joule skills creation in Joule Studio, along with key capabilities, typical use case patterns, and resources for getting started. I’ll also share a sneak peek at what lies ahead with custom AI agents in Joule Studio and how they’ll continue to evolve to support even more complex, cross-system business scenarios.

What are Joule skills?

With today's general availability release, it’s now possible to start expanding Joule’s capabilities using Joule Skills, built with skill builder in Joule Studio, to handle repetitive, rule-based tasks.

Joule skills are modular components within Joule. They leverage the contents of a conversation to complete a specific task.

Here’s a closer look at the key attributes of Joule Skills:

  • Deterministic execution: Joule Skills perform single, predefined operations. These operations can contain multiple steps, such as automations or messages. Each operation contains fixed inputs and outputs, ensuring consistent and efficient results.
  • Natural language understanding: Joule interprets different ways a user might request an operation, ensuring the correct skill is triggered, regardless of phrasing.
  • Context awareness: Joule analyzes user roles, conversation history, and business context to trigger skills only when relevant, avoiding unnecessary executions.
  • Multiple skills working together: Joule Skills are published within a single productive Joule instance, seamlessly combining SAP-provided and custom skills for a unified automation experience.

Joule skills are modular and self-contained, meaning that organizations can start leveraging them to automate everyday tasks without having to add extra layers of complexity. With Joule Studio’s open and extensible framework, skills can be integrated with SAP apps, as well as third-party APIs through SAP Build actions, so they can carry out tasks across systems automatically without needing extra steps or human input.

Explore custom skills further in the Joule Studio product tour.

Typical Use Case Patterns

Joule skills are ideal for handling common, low-complexity requests, freeing your team’s time up from routine tasks. Let’s take a look at some of the common use cases for creating custom Joule skills:

  • Navigation: Allow users to navigate seamlessly across company applications to find specific information, such as IT help resources and HR policies.
  • Data access: Enable users to retrieve, monitor, and track data such as shipping info or optimized delivery routes with real-time traffic updates.
  • System transactions: Structured workflows and system transactions — like IT ticket creation or order management — can be automated and executed via Joule.
  • Workflow execution: Enable Joule to initiate workflow and collect user input for requirements, such as hiring approval processes, facility maintenance requests, or supplier contract renewals.
  • Decision assistance: Enhance decision-making by providing pre-defined insights, such as credit risk evaluation, sales performance forecasting and warehouse demand predictions.

Of course, these only begin to cover the breadth of possibilities that Joule skills offer, as they’re deeply grounded in business data and processes. As part of SAP Build, Joule Studio has native access to all your connectors, automations, apps, and actions — enabling you to reuse assets, leverage shared APIs, and operate within a single governance framework. This tight integration eliminates duplication, accelerates delivery, and ensures consistency across your SAP Build environment. With Joule Studio’s intelligent understanding of existing automations and applications, the skills developers build are not only tailored to unique business needs but also drive real-world outcomes. 

For a deeper understanding of how Joule Studio can integrate and extend SAP and non-SAP solutions, refer to the SAP Reference Architecture within the Architecture Center: https://url.sap/xw5uq7

Several of our SAP Partners have already started to transform their everyday operations with Joule Studio and custom skills. To learn more about their use cases and experiences, check out their blog posts:

  • How sovanta uses Joule Studio to take ticketing systems to the next level
  • How Pricefx is transforming pricing software with Joule Studio in SAP Build
  • How LeverX enhances CAD Data Search for Manufacturing with Joule Studio in SAP Build

Get started creating custom Joule Skills

As we move closer to a more unified experience across SAP Build, the skill-building process is designed to feel intuitive and familiar. Joule Studio makes it easy to dive in and get started, with a setup that feels instantly familiar to anyone who's used SAP Build.

The typical design process includes:

  1. Creating a project in SAP Build: Directly from the SAP Build Lobby, initiate the skill development environment within Joule Studio.
  2. Defining metadata: Add the skill name and description to ensure discoverability, semantic clarity and intent-based Joule orchestration.
  3. Configuring inputs and outputs: Determine what Joule will request from the end user (inputs) and what it will return (outputs), enabling structured communication.
  4. Building the logic flow: Embed existing automation elements such as actions, decisions, and sub-processes with a familiar drag-and-drop simplicity.
  5. Test in the Test Environment: Test how newly created Joule Skill works within the Joule conversation. Ensure that it functions as expected and does not conflict with any other existing Joule Skills.
  6. Release and Deploy to Production: Make project available to end users by deploying it to the specified production environment.

Following SAP Build’s approach, Joule Studio enables both developers and business process experts to start creating. So, whether you’re an enterprise architect looking to extend Joule for your organization’s AI solutions, or a line of business expert hoping to simplify routine requests – Joule Studio now lets you create custom skills with drag-and-drop ease and maximum adaptability.

Completed custom Joule Skill

For a step-by-step guide on creating custom skills, check out the Interactive Value Journey: Designing custom Joule skills in Joule Studio

What’s Next: Pushing the boundaries with custom AI Agents

This is only the beginning for Joule Studio, as we’ll continue to evolve the capabilities further by introducing the agent builder in Joule Studio later this year. With custom AI agents, enterprises can unlock even more complex scenarios, bridging across multiple systems, steps, and tasks.

AI agents used for procurement scenariosHere’s a few examples of what would be possible with custom AI agents:

  • Procurement decision-making: Analyze supplier performance and market trends, helping procurement teams make informed decisions, negotiate better contracts, and ensure supply chain reliability.
  • Talent acquisition: Streamline the recruitment process by reviewing candidates based on resumes, scheduling interviews, and assisting in onboarding (e.g. gathering docs), ensuring faster and efficient hiring.
  • Logistics planning: Optimize delivery routes based on real-time traffic data, weather conditions, and carrier availability, enhancing efficiency and reducing transportation costs.

To understand more about fundamental differences between a Joule skill and agent, read this blog.

Designing a custom AI Agent in Joule Studio. With the general availability of Joule Studio, this marks a meaningful step forward in how work gets done—moving from traditional, linear automation to intelligent, adaptive systems that can handle real-world complexity. As organizations begin to explore their potential, Joule Studio will help teams work smarter, respond faster, and unlock new levels of efficiency across the enterprise.

Learn more about how to access Joule Studio and get started: Read the blog post

entry.title: How to Get Started with Joule Studio
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Miguel Angel Meza Martinez and Maria Kondratyeva

How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and AI agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency.

 

Skill Builder in Joule Studio is now Generally Available

At the heart of Joule Studio are custom Joule Skills — purpose-built, reusable logic blocks that can be tailored to your unique business needs. These skills support flexible logic and seamless integration with third-party systems, unlocking automation opportunities across domains. Whether it's retrieving weather data from an external API to inform transport planning, or assessing vendor risks via your risk management platform, Custom Joule Skills let you adapt quickly and deliver real business value.

As Joule Studio reaches General Availability, many early adopters and interested teams are asking the same essential question:

“What are the commercial and technical implications of working with Joule Studio?”

Whether you're a business decision-maker evaluating impact, a developer preparing your technical landscape, or a partner planning ahead for trial licenses — this post outlines what you need to know to get started smoothly and cost-effectively.

Pre-Requisites

Before you dive into building with Joule Studio, make sure your environment includes:

SAP Build

    • Leverage Cloud Integration Automation service scenario for SAP Build to install SAP Build Process Automation service.
    • The SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311) is required to build, test, and deploy your custom Joule Skills.

Joule

    • You will need to have Joule (base or higher).

Commercial Details

There is no additional cost for orchestration and invocation of custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio. This means you do not need AI Units to run custom Joule Skills in your production environments.

That said, it’s important to note that while the orchestration and invocation of a custom skill is free , the underlying components used by your custom Joule Skills will still follow their standard commercial models. For example, if your custom Joule Skill kicks off a business process automation, the usage of SAP Build Process Automation (BTPEA) will still be billed according to the BTPEA pricing structure.

Partner Access – TDD License

For our partners, we recognize how important it is to test, demonstrate, and develop with Joule Studio. That’s why we’re preparing a TDD (Test, Demo, Development) license, which is expected to be ready in the upcoming months. This license will be built on top of SAP Build and Joule. We’ll be sharing updates and specific guidance as we get closer to a release date.

Technical Setup

To ensure proper functionality of Joule Studio within an SAP BTP environment, a defined technical setup process is required. This process establishes secure identity trust, enables core service dependencies, and configures cross-component communication essential for custom Joule Skills orchestration and runtime execution.

At the core of the setup is the need to establish trust between your SAP BTP subaccount and your Identity Authentication tenant.  This trust configuration is mandatory to enable user authentication and token-based authorization flows between Joule Studio and other SAP services.

Concurrently, it is necessary to map user attributes within the SAP Cloud Identity Directory. These attribute mappings (e.g., email, user ID, first name, last name, groups, etc.) are used to support user context resolution and enforce authorization policies during skill execution.

Following trust and attribute configuration, the Joule Booster must be executed. This booster is a guided setup workflow available in SAP BTP and is responsible for:

  • Automatically provisioning required service instances and entitlements
  • Binding SAP Build (build_default service plan) to a productive Joule instance
  • Activating SAP Cloud Identity Services dependencies
  • Validating identity configuration and connectivity across services

The full technical configuration process is documented in the official Joule Studio Set-Up Guide, available in the SAP Help Portal. It is strongly recommended that system administrators follow the documentation precisely, as manual misconfiguration can result in authentication failures, missing service bindings, or broken orchestration flows.

Migration Considerations for Existing SAP Build Customers

Currently, there is no automated or seamless migration path for customers who have previously subscribed to standalone SAP Build services under older SKUs or who have developed content in subaccounts that are not aligned with the new license model required by Joule Studio.

This means that some manual configuration is required at the BTP subaccount level if you wish to transition existing SBPA projects into a new Joule-enabled environment.

Manual Configuration Steps:

  • You will need to create a new SAP BTP subaccount and subscribe to SAP Build using the build_default service plan associated with the new SKU.
  • Within this subaccount, make sure you also subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation, as it is a foundational runtime component for custom Joule Skills that trigger workflows or automations.

Once the new subaccount is configured, you can manually migrate existing SBPA content (such as processes, and automations) using export and import functionality provided by SAP Build tools. It’s important to note that this process is not automatic and may require some post-import validation to ensure dependencies (e.g., destinations, service bindings, user roles) are correctly mapped in the new environment.

This limitation applies only to content developed prior to the transition. Once you are operating within the Joule-enabled subaccount, all newly created content will be natively compatible with Joule Studio and will not require further migration effort.

This is a one-time effort but depending on the complexity of your current SBPA landscape, it may require significant administrative coordination — especially if your original environment includes cross-system integrations, custom scripting logic, or a large number of interdependent workflows.

💡Tip: Before initiating a full migration, consider whether all existing content truly needs to be moved. In many cases, only selected automations and apps need to be reused or triggered from the new environment, while other can continue to run temporarily in the original tenant. This can reduce complexity and allow for a phased migration strategy, where only the most critical elements are prioritized for transition, while others are gradually retired, redesigned, or rebuilt in Joule Studio as needed.

Looking Ahead: What’s Next

Joule Studio is launching with a clear, accessible model: no AI Unit consumption and no additional orchestration cost for custom Joule Skills built with current features. This gives teams a solid foundation to explore, prototype, and scale — without friction.

But this is only the start.

Looking ahead, new SAP Build license will introduce a pay-as-you-go (PAYG) model, providing greater flexibility for customers to adopt Joule Studio capabilities incrementally — without needing a full upfront subscription. This is especially valuable for teams piloting new use cases or scaling adoption gradually.

In addition, a Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license is planned to support SAP partners with dedicated, hands-on environments for prototyping and showcasing Joule-enabled experiences.

As the Joule Studio evolves — with features like AI Agents on the horizon — the commercial model may adapt to reflect expanded functionality. Any changes will be communicated clearly and ahead of time.

 

Get to Know Joule Studio

💾Architecture Overview

📹Joule Skill Demo Video

📹Smart Advisory Companion – Inspiration Video

🧭 Product Tour

❓FAQ

entry.title: Joule Studio Empowers Enterprises to Build Intelligent AI Skills
entry.content:
Authors: @Trinidad & @jacobahtan 

As businesses adopt AI at an accelerated pace, the need for AI tools that deeply understand enterprise processes becomes critical. SAP Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, is designed to address this need—offering intelligent, contextual, and secure assistance across the SAP ecosystem.

But what if the out-of-the-box AI capabilities don’t fully match your business needs? Enter SAP Joule Studio, a powerful low-code tool that enables you to build your own Joule Skills, tailor-made for your organization’s workflows.

This blog explores how Joule Studio empowers companies to create custom AI skills, automate repetitive tasks, and seamlessly integrate AI into daily operations.

This is a summary of the business use case I presented together with my colleague @Trinidad in this webinar: Amplify Joule's power for your enterprise needs. Please, note the mentioned session is part of a series of webinars under the topic of “Talk to Your Business with Generative AI”. Check the full calendar here to watch the recordings of past sessions and register for the upcoming one.

 

💡 What is SAP Joule?

SAP Joule is an AI copilot designed to provide intelligent, contextual assistance within the SAP ecosystem. Unlike generic AI chatbots, Joule understands SAP business processes, user context, and role-based permissions, allowing it to deliver meaningful, secure, and actionable responses.

🌐 Unified Across the SAP Ecosystem

  • Joule acts as a single AI instance connected to SAP Cloud solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, and SAP Field Service Management (FSM).
  • Users can interact with Joule via an embedded web client, mobile interface (e.g., SAP Mobile Start), or third-party tools like Microsoft Teams.
  • Regardless of the entry point, Joule maintains user context, security, and session continuity.

🤖 Joule's Capabilities: How Does It Work?

When a user interacts with Joule, here’s what happens under the hood

  1. User Input: A natural language query is entered e.g., “Show me open purchase orders for customer ABC.”

  2. Intent Recognition: Joule checks if the query matches:
    • An out-of-the-box skill (prebuilt by SAP)
    • A custom skill developed by the partner/customer
    • Or if it requires a knowledge-based response (e.g., documents or help articles)

  3. Knowledge Filtering: Joule pulls information from:
    • SAP documentation
    • The customer’s own document repositories (document grounding)
    • Application-specific data (e.g., SAP S/4HANA)

  4. Context Gathering:
    • Who is the user?
    • What are their roles, permissions, and session context?
    • What application are they working in?

  5. Query Orchestration:
    • Joule composes an enriched, context-aware query.
    • This is passed to a Large Language Model (LLM) like GPT or Gemini for dialogue generation.

  6. Skill Execution:
    • If the response requires action (e.g., “Create a service ticket”), Joule invokes the appropriate skill or API.

  7. Response Delivery:
    • The answer or action is returned to the user, formatted appropriately (e.g., text, links, buttons).

⚙️ Joule Skills vs. AI Agents: Understanding the Difference

🔧 Joule Skills: Deterministic Automation

Purpose: Automate structured, repetitive tasks with predefined logic.
How it works: When a query matches a defined intent, the corresponding skill executes a fixed workflow.
Example Use Cases:

  • Checking contract validity
  • Retrieving customer orders
  • Creating service tickets

Characteristics:

  • Rule-based
  • Fast and reliable
  • Requires clear input/output definitions

🧠  AI Agents: Dynamic, Reasoning-Powered Automation (Coming Soon)

Purpose: Handle complex tasks with ambiguous goals, requiring reasoning and decision-making.
How it works:

  • Breaks tasks into subtasks autonomously
  • Chooses which APIs, skills, or tools to use
  • Adjusts the execution path based on real-time context

Example Use Cases:

  • Supply chain disruption management (e.g., predicting and mitigating shipment delays)
  • Cross-system troubleshooting with adaptive workflows

Characteristics:

  • Autonomous planning
  • Uses LLMs for reasoning
  • Dynamic execution paths

🔑 In Simple Terms

Skills: “Tell me what to do, and I’ll do it.”

Agents: “Tell me the goal, and I’ll figure out how to get there.”

 

Joule Studio

... is a new tool within SAP Build that lets partners, developers, and customers create, manage, and deploy Joule Skills—custom AI-driven capabilities that extend the functionality of SAP Joule.

✅ Why Joule Studio Matters

  • Automates routine tasks using natural language.
  • Provides an easy-to-use, low-code/no-code interface.
  • Empowers business users and developers to extend SAP Joule without writing extensive code.
  • Seamlessly integrates with both SAP systems and third-party applications.

🎯 Business Value

  • Accelerates productivity by reducing manual work.
  • Provides consistent, AI-powered user experiences across the SAP landscape.
  • Reduces reliance on developers for routine automation tasks.
  • Allows businesses to adapt SAP Joule to their unique processes.

🔧 What are Joule Skills?

Joule Skills are modular AI capabilities that automate deterministic, rule-based tasks in response to natural language queries from users. These tasks are repeatable, well-structured, and follow predefined workflows.

🔍 Examples of Joule Skills

✅ Check if a customer’s service contract is valid in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
✅ Retrieve a list of recent purchase orders.
✅ Generate a service ticket in SAP Field Service Management (FSM).
✅ Fetch relevant SAP documentation based on a keyword or phrase.

🚀 Key Capabilities of Joule Skills

  1. Automate processes based on natural language prompts.
  2. Fetch data, perform transactions, or trigger workflows.
  3. Integrate with APIs, SAP backend systems, or third-party apps.
  4. Provide formatted outputs like lists, summaries, or direct links to SAP systems.

 

🏗️  Building Skills in Joule Studio: How Does it Work?

1. Visual Skill Builder

  • Joule Studio uses a drag-and-drop interface to design skills.
  • Define inputs, outputs, and processing steps without complex coding.

2. API and Action Integration

  • Create actions that connect to SAP APIs (e.g., S/4HANA, FSM) or third-party systems.
  • Support for importing OpenAPI specifications simplifies the process.
  • Create custom REST calls easily within the skill.

3. Workflow Orchestration

  • Chain multiple actions together.
  • Add conditions, branching logic, or loops.
  • Incorporate SAP Build Process Automation workflows or decisions.

4. Response Customization

  • Define how outputs are presented:
    • Text summaries
    • Lists with links (e.g., to a contract or service call)
    • Status updates
  • Full control over the user interaction format.

5. Secure Deployment via Environments

  • Deploy skills into specific environments (Dev, QA, Production).
  • Manage role-based access for both developers and users.
  • Enforce security with principal propagation and identity checks.

6. Monitoring & Lifecycle Management

  • Visualize skill execution paths.
  • Debug failed steps directly within Joule Studio.
  • Manage skill versions and rollback if needed.

🧠 How Joule Skills Enhance SAP Joule

  1. Deep Contextual Awareness: Skills leverage user identity, permissions, and current session context, ensuring responses are both relevant and secure.
  2. Unified Access: Users can invoke skills from within any SAP application where Joule is embedded, without switching apps or screens.
  3. Extensibility: You can extend SAP’s out-of-the-box skills by layering in your company-specific logic, processes, or data sources.

 

🏗️ Example Use Case: Smart Advisory Companion

🏢 Business Problem

A consultant named John needs to handle customer requests like “How do I implement multi-tenancy in SAP BTP?”. Today, John manually checks contract validity, looks for similar projects, gathers documents, creates service calls, and emails customers—a time-consuming process.

💡 Solution with Joule Studio

Joule Studio powers five key Joule Skills that automate this workflow:

1. Check Service Contract Validity:

Queries S/4HANA Cloud to check if the customer’s service contract is active. If expired, sends John a link to renew it.

2. Find Similar Projects:

Connects to a backend that uses SAP HANA Cloud’s Vector Engine for semantic search, retrieving the most relevant past projects.

3. Retrieve Related Documents:

Searches for relevant SAP documentation or internal files based on the customer’s request.

4. Create a Service Call:

Automatically logs a service ticket in SAP FSM, using data gathered from previous steps.

5. Send Summary Email:

Automatically composes and sends a summary email to the customer, containing all gathered information, ticket IDs, document links, and next steps.

🎯Result

John spends less time navigating systems and more time delivering value to customers.

🏛️ Solution Architecture for the Use Case

Component

Functionality

SAP Joule Studio

Skill authoring, deployment, lifecycle management

SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Service contract validation

SAP FSM

Service call creation

Smart Advisory Backend

Semantic search using vector databases

SAP HANA Cloud

Data storage, vector search, knowledge graph

SAP Build Process Automation

Email workflows, task management

Generative AI Hub

LLMs for document analysis or summarization

 

🏗️ Setting Up the Foundation: Joule Studio Environment

✔️Environment Creation

  • A Joule Studio Environment acts as a sandbox where you can develop, test, and deploy your Joule Skills.
  • It controls the deployment versions and provides isolation between development, QA, and production.

✔️Connecting Systems via Destinations

  • The team set up Destinations in SAP BTP for:
  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud (contract validation)
  2. SAP FSM (service ticket creation)
  3. A Custom Smart Advisory Backend (handles semantic search and knowledge graphs)
  • Destinations allow Joule Skills to securely communicate with SAP APIs and third-party services.

✔️Action Projects: How to “bridge” your Destinations with Joule Skills

1. Import from API Specification:

  • Upload your OpenAPI-formatted API specification file.
  • Select specific endpoints you need – no need for everything.
  • Test endpoints immediately to define accurate outputs.
  • System auto-generates output fields, which you can then refine.

2. Define Custom Actions:

  • Manually configure endpoints and parameters.
  • Ideal for custom integrations (e.g., S/4HANA Service Contracts).
  • Test to automatically generate and then modify output fields.

Creating Your Joule Skill Project

Once your actions are defined:

  • In the lobby, select "Joule Skill."
  • Give it a clear name and, crucially, a very specific description. This clarity is vital for effective utilization.

 

🛠️ Deep Dive of Joule Skills Development for our Use Case

🔍 Skill 1: Retrieve Similar Projects

Purpose: Search for top 5 similar projects based on a natural language query.

Process:

  1. Created an Action Project by importing an OpenAPI specification from the backend.
  2. Defined the API endpoint to query the vector database that holds historical project embeddings.
  3. Defined input (search term) and output (project list) parameters.
  4. Created a Joule Skill named Retrieve Similar Projects.
  5. The skill was configured to automatically generate a user-friendly list with project titles and links.

Result: John can type “Find me similar projects about multi-tenancy” and Joule returns a clickable list of past projects.

📄 Skill 2: Retrieve SAP Documents

Purpose: Retrieve SAP-related documents relevant to the query.

Process:

  1. Added an action that queries a document repository API (e.g., SAP Help, SharePoint).
  2. Configured a Send Message step to customize how the documents are displayed (title, snippet, document type, and clickable links).
  3. Disabled automatic response formatting to fully control how Joule presents the information.

Result: John asks “Show me documents about ABAP Cloud”, and Joule returns a curated list of relevant documentation with descriptions and links.

📝 Skill 3: Check Service Contract Validity

Purpose: Verify whether a customer’s service contract in S/4HANA Cloud is active or expired.

Process:

  1. Created an action to call the Get Service Contract API from S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Defined input as the Service Contract ID.
  3. Built a Condition Branch to check whether the contract status contains the string “Active”.
  4. Configured two possible outcomes:
    - If active: returns a confirmation message.
    - If expired: displays a message with a button linking to the contract for renewal.

Result: John can input “Check contract SC-0001” and Joule tells him whether it’s valid or expired, with quick navigation links.

🔧 Skill 4: Create Service Call in FSM

Purpose: Open a service call in SAP FSM based on the current advisory conversation.

Process:

  1. Confirmed the service contract validity using the skill from the previous step.
  2. If valid, created an action to call FSM’s Create Service Call API.
  3. Populated the service call details using information gathered (e.g., subject from John’s advisory request).
  4. Designed the output message to include:
    - The Service Call ID.
    - A link to the FSM interface for further details.
    - Status and remarks.

Result: With a simple command like “Open a service call for this customer”, Joule creates the FSM ticket instantly.

📧 Skill 5: Send Summary Email

Purpose: Summarize the conversation and send an email to the customer or internal stakeholders.

Process:

  1. Used SAP Build Process Automation to handle email sending.
  2. Created a Process Project for email with parameters like:
    - To and CC email addresses.
    - Email body parts.
    - Subject line.
  3. Published this process into the Joule Studio library.
  4. Built a Joule Skill to trigger the process as part of the workflow.

Result: John types “Send a summary email”, and Joule automatically drafts and sends a detailed email containing:
- Contract status.
- List of related projects.
- Documents.
- Service call details.

Use Case end-to-end Demonstration

🧠 Key Features Showcased in the Demo

  1. Dynamic Input Handling: Skills captured user prompts dynamically (e.g., keywords, contract IDs).
  2. API Testing Built-In: While creating actions, the API responses were tested in real-time to auto-generate output fields.
  3. Decision Branching: Contract validation skill used IF/THEN logic directly in the visual flow.
  4. Data Formatting: Output lists, clickable links, and summaries were customized for each skill.
  5. Environment Management: Demonstrated deploying skills into the testing environment with destination mappings.
  6. Error Handling: Skills were designed with fallback messages in case of API failures or missing data.

 

🔭 What’s Next for Joule Studio?

🚩 July 2025:

✅ GA (General Availability) of Joule Studio for Custom Skills.

🚀 Later in 2025:

✅ AI Agents Development:

  • Leverages the same framework.
  • Adds autonomous planning, multi-step reasoning, and complex problem solving.
  • The presenters concluded by giving a teaser of the next evolution—AI Agents—which will further extend Joule’s capabilities by introducing autonomous, multi-step reasoning and decision-making, enabling even more complex workflows beyond deterministic skills.

 

📚 Learning Resources and Next Steps:

  • Explore the SAP Joule Product Page (placeholder link)
  • Join the SAP AI Community to connect with experts
  • Review the SAP Roadmap for upcoming features
  • Watch our Webinar Recording to revisit the detailed demo and implementation guide

 

✨ Conclusion: Your Enterprise, Smarter with Joule Studio

Joule Studio transforms how businesses interact with SAP systems. By enabling you to build custom Joule Skills, you automate routine tasks, reduce operational complexity, and unlock the power of natural language-driven workflows.

This isn’t just automation—it’s intelligent, context-aware assistance designed for enterprise scale, security, and flexibility.

As the evolution continues with AI Agents, Joule Studio will be the central hub where your AI-driven enterprise solutions come to life.

entry.title: Say Hi to Joule in SAP Activate road map viewer
entry.content:
At SAP, we continually listen to our customers and strive to enhance their experience with SAP Activate. A primary focus is simplifying daily tasks and ensuring more uniform processes.

Managing an SAP implementation project can be complicated due to numerous tasks, dependencies, and stakeholders. The SAP Activate roadmap viewer in SAP for Me streamlines this by offering partners and customers standardized, structured, and role-specific implementation guidance. This ensures project teams receive relevant, up-to-date information and guidance throughout the entire implementation process, reducing clutter and boosting productivity.

However, using the SAP Activate road map viewer to find the necessary information can be challenging and time-consuming.

That’s why we’re excited to announce the general availability of Joule in the SAP Activate road map viewer. With Joule, customers and partners can now easily ask their Activate-related questions to receive clear responses and unlock greater value.

In this post, I will detail what is available today: Joule is accessible to all SAP for Me users for two of our most popular road maps.

  1. SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - New Implementation
  2. SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape)

Fig: Joule Icon in SAP Activate road map viewer

In summary, Joule in the SAP Activate road map viewer helps project teams remain focused, organized, and efficient by addressing all their implementation questions.

Start using Joule today to enjoy a smarter approach to SAP Activate!

Please share your feedback with us!

Your SAP Activate Team

entry.title: The AI Stack Is Ready — Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology
entry.content:
The Challenge No Longer Is Technology

Having worked hands-on with enterprise software for close to three decades, I’ve seen countless technology shifts — some promising incremental gains, others causing deep industry disruption. But none of them — none — have matured as quickly and as loudly as GenAI.

 

We are no longer in the “wait and see” phase. The stack is here. The APIs are mature. The building blocks — from LLMs to vector databases and orchestration frameworks — are all operational. There’s no question that we now have the technological backbone to deliver GenAI-enabled solutions across practically any business function.

Even common criticisms like hallucinations are being actively addressed. With test-time compute techniques — like prompt engineering, function calling, retrieval-augmented generation, and tool usage — hallucinations are kept at bay, quality radically increases, and results become not only reliable but robust. These advances prove a critical point: most GenAI objectives are technically attainable today.

Sure, the LLMs will continue to evolve, improving in reasoning and domain specialization. But they are already good enough to be effectively leveraged in real-world workflows — assuming the right usage patterns, guardrails, and integration strategies are in place.

So if tech is no longer the bottleneck… what is?

 

The Real Challenge: Ideas and Governance

Once upon a time, our hardest problem was figuring out how to make the tech work. Today, the hardest problem is figuring out what to build, how to deploy it responsibly, and how to scale and govern it across a rapidly shifting organizational landscape.

Think about it: spinning up a chatbot with retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) is no longer a moonshot. Hooking up a vector DB to your internal documents, embedding GenAI into Fiori apps or ABAP logic, orchestrating workflows with agentic logic — this is all doable. But what’s much harder is identifying high-value, sustainable use cases and creating a framework that doesn’t devolve into chaos as teams independently launch proof-of-concepts without strategy or alignment.

 

Why Ideation Matters More Than Ever

Let’s be honest: the biggest risk with GenAI today isn’t that the models don’t work — it’s that either we’re not building enough or we’re building too much, too fast, and too randomly. Every team spins up their own assistant. Use cases are vague. Nothing talks to each other. No reuse. No alignment. That’s not innovation — that’s chaos.

 

We’ve moved past the stage where the question is “Can we build this?”

Now it’s about “Should we build it?”

And even more importantly: “How do we keep it working well over time?”

 

This is why ideation can’t just be a sticky note exercise or a quick prompt storming session in ChatGPT. We have to treat it with the same rigor we apply to architecture. That means thinking about the business context, designing for scale, and planning for long-term sustainability — not just the MVP.

And here’s where the tough questions start to pop up — the ones we should be asking upfront:

  • Are we using the most effective language model from a quality vs. cost perspective?
  • Are we selecting the fastest possible model for latency-sensitive workflows? (If you’re doing multi-agent interactions, speed matters a lot.)
  • How is the quality of the responses behaving over time? Are we tracking degradation or drift?
  • What’s our strategy for testing newer LLMs as they come out? Should we switch? If so, how do we regression test across use cases without breaking things?
  • As our knowledge base grows, are we managing it properly? Is it staying focused, or are we bloating it with irrelevant context that just confuses the model?

These aren’t just technical questions. These are product and platform questions. And unless we ask them early — during ideation — we risk building solutions that are impressive in a demo but fragile, expensive, or completely unmaintainable in production.

Ideation today needs to account for all of this. It’s not just about dreaming big — it’s about designing smart.

 

Governance: From One-Off Demos to Scalable Systems

Without governance, GenAI becomes a set of disconnected experiments. With governance, it becomes an enabler of business-wide transformation.

This governance isn’t just about policies or committees. It’s about having:

  • Reusable components (tools, prompts, agents)
  • Common platforms (secured access to LLMs, retrievers, memory)
  • Evaluation metrics (accuracy, drift, hallucination tracking)
  • Ownership models (who builds, who maintains, who retrains)

 

Organizations that don’t invest here will be stuck in demo land. Those that do? They’ll build AI capabilities into their operational DNA — from support, finance, and HR to production and logistics.

 

FinOps: The Overlooked Layer of GenAI Operations

Another area that absolutely needs attention is FinOps — because GenAI might be easy to spin up, but it can get expensive fast.

Where are we spending the most? Are the solutions optimized from a cost perspective, or are we overpaying for high-end models when cheaper alternatives would do the job? And more importantly, how do we split the overall bill across different teams or functions using different LLM providers?

If multiple agents are running on different models — OpenAI for one workflow, Mistral or Claude for another — how do we assign those costs back to the right cost centers? Who’s consuming what? Are we operating in a user-payer model? Or is everything being lumped into a single invoice no one can untangle?

These questions need to be addressed before GenAI gets deeply embedded into everyday operations. Without visibility and accountability, you risk not only spiraling costs but also poor architectural decisions driven by unclear usage patterns.

FinOps isn’t just finance’s problem — it’s part of good governance.

 

The Role of Architects and Tech Leaders

This is where it gets personal for me.

As someone who’s been on the architecture side of SAP, building custom solutions for large enterprises, I see a massive opportunity — and responsibility. Our role as architects and tech leaders is evolving.

We’re not just evaluating frameworks and drawing diagrams anymore. We’re setting the tone for AI readiness. We’re defining guardrails, pushing for smart reusability, and fostering the right kind of innovation — not the “one demo per team” variety, but the kind that results in sustainable business improvement.

 

So… Are You Ready

You don’t need to wait for the perfect model or the next framework release. The AI stack is ready. The frontier now is not technical — it’s organizational.

  • If you’re a builder: build with intent.
  • If you’re a strategist: align use cases with value.
  • If you’re a leader: create clarity and structure.

Because in the GenAI era, the best ideas — not the best tech — will win.

entry.title: How Redwood augments workload automation with AI using Joule Studio in SAP Build
entry.content:
Hello SAP community, my name is Gerben Blom, Field CTO with Redwood Software. I have been part of the SAP community for the last 2 decades support the Redwood partnership with SAP and our joint customer base. I am very exited with the recent developments in our partnership where we started to explore the strength of our combined product developments to enable the best outcomes in their business processes. In this blog post we will explain how the Redwood workload automation engine can be used with Joule Studio to simplify the access to backend processes and information for the business user leveraging Joule.

Introduction

For over twenty years, Redwood Software has partnered with SAP to help customers automate their most complex and mission-critical processes. RunMyJobs by Redwood stands out as a leader in the Service Orchestration and Automation Platform  (SOAP) sector and is uniquely recognized as the only Workload Automation (WLA) solution that is an SAP-endorsed app. It offers extensive integration along with a wide array of templates and connectors that serve both established on-premises systems and modern cloud and AI-driven SAP technologies. 

SAP Premium certification strengthens RunMyJobs’ alignment with SAP’s clean core strategy. It expands SAP job scheduling without custom code or workarounds that create friction and technical debt, enabling customers to maximize their SAP investments. 

Why we jumped on Joule Studio 

When SAP introduced Joule Studio— latest SAP Build capability, that allows to create custom Joule skills for unique business needs. —we saw a fast path to embed our deep scheduling expertise directly inside SAP’s business copilot, Joule. The ambition was clear: give every planner, analyst, or other line of business practitioner instant, AI-powered answers without leaving chat. 

From Fragmented Interfaces to One-Ask Insights 

Imagine checking the status of a long, overnight Material Requirements Planning (MRP) run. Yesterday, that meant hopping between SAP screens and RunMyJobs dashboards—or logging a ticket and waiting. Today, a planner simply types: 

“What’s the status of today’s MRP run?”  

Because Joule Studio’s open, API-first design lets us wire RunMyJobs actions straight into SAP transactions and data through its easy drag-and-drop interface, Joule now calls the RunMyJobs API, pulls live data, and responds instantly in the same chat. There is no swivel chair, delay, or maze of UIs—just the clarity every SLA demands. 

See it in action here!

How the Redwood Team Built the Custom Skill 

  • Mapped the conversation - We started by capturing the natural language questions planners ask (“Is the MRP job finished?” “Did any steps fail?”). 
  • Dragged in RunMyJobs actions - Joule Studio’s canvas lets us drop our existing execute Job and check for Job status API calls as a reusable action, passing in GLOBAL.MRPStatusCheck as the Job to track, set authentication once, and drag-connect it to the natural-language intent. 
  • Grounded the data. We exposed the specific MRP job metadata Joule needs—run ID, plant, SLA threshold—so responses are contextual, not generic. 
  • Added guardrails and tests. Joule Studio’s built-in test harness lets us simulate edge cases (time-outs, partial failures) before anything hits production, giving both IT and business teams confidence. 
  • Deployed with governance. Because RunMyJobs is already premium certified as an SAP Endorsed App, the skill sailed through clean core checks and appears in the Joule Studio catalog (MRP Run Check) ready for self-service activation. 

Joule Studio: An open and extensible framework built for outcomes 

Joule Studio enables partners like Redwood to expand Joule's capabilities by creating custom skills that manage system transitions behind the scenes. This approach spares users from having to navigate multiple user interfaces while ensuring reliable outcomes. Joule Studio offers a simple drag-and-drop interface, allowing users to reuse existing SAP Build actions, which accelerates the development and deployment of these skills. Additionally, we found that with the unified governance and lifecycle management of Joule skills available before deployment, Redwood developers can confidently roll out these custom skills from the development environment into production. 

An open and extensible framework is Joule Studio’s distinct value pillar (alongside deep business grounding and built-in security and compliance). Partner integrations such as RunMyJobs by Redwood bring that pillar to life for business and user impact: 

- One integration layer: Connect to any third-party application for data and insights easily, so IT can skip fragile glue code and focus on orchestration. 

- Industry accelerators: Partners can package vertical logic—predictive yield for agriculture, just-in-time procurement for manufacturing, anomaly detection for oil & gas—to deliver results, not just tools. 

Joule Studio unlocks the potential for partners and developers to craft even more powerful, AI-first capabilities that align with every business process. By encapsulating back-office automation as Joule skills, partners can expose complex workflows—from dispute resolution to predictive maintenance—through a single conversational interface prompt.

Conclusion and next steps

Redwood envisions a future where AI agents make Service Orchestration and Automation Platforms (SOAP) an integral part of the daily experience for business users, not just a backend tool for IT. Rather than being seen as a bolt-on to SAP systems, automation fabrics become native, empowering business users with the same speed, precision, and reliability IT teams have relied on for decades. Redwood is looking forward to the agent builder capability in Joule Studio when it goes live. 

Redwood and SAP are co-innovating to turn complex enterprise workloads into simple skills with Joule Studio. Take IT tickets into time saved, complexity into clarity, and automation into conversations. See how easily you can build powerful, real-time skills with Joule Studio. 

👉 Click here to learn more about how to use Joule Studio.

entry.title: Securing Agentic AI Through Threat Modeling at SAP
entry.content:
By Helen Oakley, Senior Director of Software and AI Security, SAP Global Security & Cloud Compliance 

This year, at SAP Sapphire, SAP unveiled its expanded vision for Business AI, introducing a growing network of Joule Agents that work across systems and lines of business. This marks a clear step into the era of Agentic AI – systems that can understand context, take initiative, and drive outcomes autonomously. “SAP combines the world’s most powerful suite of business applications with uniquely rich data and the latest AI innovations to create a flywheel of customer value,” said CEO Christian Klein. While this evolution opens exciting possibilities for automation and productivity, it also introduces a new layer of complexity in how we approach security. Agentic systems challenge traditional safeguards, making it essential to identify and mitigate risks early through tailored threat modeling. 

At its core, threat modeling is about asking the right questions early in the development process, while the system is still being designed and built. Rather than simply looking for bugs or code flaws, it forces us to think through how a system might behave in the real world. What could go wrong if an agent’s goals are manipulated? Could someone poison its memory over time? What if an agent uses a tool in an unintended or unsafe way? How could agent-generated content be used to mislead or overload human decision-makers? What happens when agents collaborate or collide in ways that expose the system to cascading failures or manipulation? 

These are not hypothetical questions. They reflect the real and emerging risks of agentic systems. The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide is a valuable resource that brings structure to this thinking. It highlights specific threats such as memory poisoning, cascading hallucinations, privilege compromise, and agent communication poisoning. For teams building these systems, it helps provide a common vocabulary and practical examples to guide threat modeling work. 

To give an example of how threat modeling helps in practice, let’s take the case of goal manipulation – one of the emerging risks identified in the OWASP guide. In agentic systems, attackers don’t necessarily need to exploit traditional software flaws. Instead, they can attempt to influence an agent’s behavior over time by subtly manipulating its objectives. This might happen through indirect prompt injection, compromised data sources, or crafted tool responses. Imagine an agent responsible for prioritizing financial transactions; if adversarial inputs gradually shift its decision logic, it could start approving risky payments outside of the intended policy. In threat modeling exercises, we explore how such scenarios could play out by analyzing how the agent forms and updates its goals, how memory and feedback loops could reinforce undesired behaviors, and how downstream actions might be impacted. This helps define targeted mitigations, such as isolating goal-setting logic from external inputs, monitoring shifts in agent behavior, and adding human validation for sensitive decisions. 

The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide provides a helpful reference architecture that illustrates where these types of risks can emerge. The diagram below maps threats to key components in a typical agentic system, making it easier to visualize how threat modeling applies in practice. 

Image Source: OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations guide, “Threat Model Summary” 

At SAP, threat modeling has long been part of our Secure Software Development and Operations Lifecycle (Secure SDOL), which is certified under ISO 27001. This framework ensures security is built into every phase of the product lifecycle, from design to operations. With Agentic AI, we are expanding our threat modeling approach to address risks that don’t typically appear in traditional application security. This includes analyzing agent memory behavior, reasoning patterns, system autonomy, human interaction points, and the dynamics of multi-agent ecosystems. The focus shifts from identifying static vulnerabilities to understanding how autonomy and learning can lead to unintended behaviors. From there, we define appropriate controls and mitigations to reduce those risks. 

The field of Agentic AI security continues to take shape. Standards like ISO 42001 and regulations such as the EU AI Act are in development, and industry best practices are actively maturing. That’s why collaboration is essential. SAP is contributing to the conversations held with industry groups focused on these challenges, including OWASP GenAI initiatives. We’re not just adopting ideas, we’re helping shape them, working with peers and regulators to advance the state of AI security. Our teams bring deep expertise in both enterprise security and AI systems, offering a perspective that’s helping guide how the broader ecosystem approaches agentic risks. 

Transparency remains central to how SAP approaches product security. As we continue evolving our work with AI, we’re committed to sharing what we learn through resources like the SAP Trust Center. Security is not a one-time effort. It is a continuous process, especially with systems as dynamic as Agentic AI. 

Threat modeling helps us stay ahead of these evolving risks and supports the design of systems that are both capable and safe. As Agentic AI becomes more embedded in enterprise workflows, this kind of proactive thinking becomes essential. 

SAP is proud to contribute to shaping the future of secure AI. By collaborating across the industry and applying deep expertise from our teams, we’re helping advance practical, forward-looking approaches to securing the next generation of intelligent systems.

Transcription 

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for July the 17th, 2025.

[Daniel] Big news this week, Joule Studio was released. Joule Studio is the new tool within SAP Build that lets you create your own custom skills for Joule. In other words, you can define what prompts Joule responds to and also define the messages and data to display in response to those prompts. Michael Ameling, president of BTP, announced the release in his blog. Maria Kantroncheva, a product manager, also wrote a blog about the details of the commercial model and what landscapes you can install Joule Studio on. Here she is in an exclusive interview with Developer News describing some of the capabilities.

So you can start building your own custom Joule skills by bringing any application or any data service or any system transactions to your Joule. In addition, a set of learning materials were released so you can start creating Joule skills. First, there was a product tour click-through where you can see the UI and some of the key capabilities. A video was released showing you step -by-step how to create your first skill. And a set of very detailed tutorials were released within the developer tutorial area that shows you how to create skills, including several different skills, so you can see how to use processes and actions within your skills. Michael, Maria, and Miguel Meza -Martinez, another product manager, also described how agents will soon be added to the things that you can create within Joule Studio. Here is Miguel talking about those plans.

[Miguel] Hi, everyone. I'm thrilled to announce that Joule Studio Skill Builder is now generally available. You can finally make Joule your jewel. But this is just the beginning. Please stay tuned for AI agent capabilities coming to Joule Studio later this year.

[Daniel] I will leave links to the videos, to the blogs, to the click-through tour, and to the tutorials in the description.

[Witalij] Summary, AI-assisted commenting, say AI again, I dare you, I double dare you, okay, okay, okay let me talk about dashboard design best practices then. As a part of this series of blog posts the new one has been published and it is focused on template types, layout settings, theming and so on. Links are in the description.

[Nico] Hi everyone and welcome to the SAP Developer News. The UI5 team just recently published the legacy free version of SAPUI5 and OpenUI5 which can now test and check out. They removed all the deprecated code and APIs and it includes the modular bootstrap for example which increases performance and it's now ready for you to test out. Do not use it in production rather use it in development to make sure your UI5 apps are future proof. Check out the link in the description for more information and hope to talk to you soon. Bye.

[Antonio and Ajay] Hola, SAP developers. So it's been an eventful week. You know, we've been running quite a few CodeJams this week, all focusing on SAP Integration Suite, right? So we've been running CodeJams. I started in Madrid and then in Abu Dhabi. And then, well, now we are here in India, but all CodeJams actually took place in India. So tell us a bit more about the CodeJams in India. Yeah, so we had quite a lot of CodeJam we already did, starting on Monday, where we had our first CodeJam in Colgate in Mumbai. And then it was followed by the second CodeJam that we had in Hyderabad. So we flew to Hyderabad and we had the second CodeJam related to Advanced Event Mesh at Hyderabad Mindset. And yesterday we had it in Infosys campus and again it was the Advanced Event Mesh Integration Suite CodeJam that we ran there and today we are here in SAP Bangalore SAP Labs Bangalore doing event -driven processes in SAP Build Process Automation and tomorrow we are going to Pineset and we will do a Code Jam there connecting systems and services using Integration Suite. So what else, Antonio? Well, it's a pretty packed week, I would say. So yeah, just remember that you can obviously request CodeJams via the SAP Community website. Just visit the SAP CodeJams group. And all the details there and all the different topics that we do as CodeJams are also listed there. So do check it out. And remember, CodeJams are a great, easy way to get familiar with different SAP BTP technologies. so looking forward to meeting you in a future CodeJam. yeah bye

[Rich] Hey folks Rich Heilman here. I hope everyone is doing well i just wanted to pop on here and let you all know that the session catalog is now live for SAP TechEd 2025 in Berlin the teams are working really hard to bring back the magic of TechEds of the past and that includes great content from our SAP experts from the catalog you can filter down the sessions by track session type session experience level and others you can browse deep dive sessions hands-on workshops roadmaps and strategy talks and click to add them to your favorites this is also the same place where you'll be able to reserve your seats for hands-on workshops when that piece goes live. We are all really excited to get everyone back together and bring everyone home in Berlin. So check out the session catalog, see what we have to offer this year, and register today. And we'll see you in Berlin. Bye for now.

[Thomas] In this news segment, I'd like to talk to you about the Application Front-end Service. It's a relatively new service offering in SAP BTP. It's only been available for a couple of months. It is a service that is designed to help you with building the deployment and the managing of the front end portions of your application. So it can help you deploy your SAPUI5 Fiori applications in conjunction with ABAP or CAP backends. Now it's very similar to the functionality provided by both the application router and if you've ever used it the HTML5 repository in the old Neo environment. In fact, it wants to deliver many of the same features and capabilities, but do so in a centralized managed service so you're not having to deal with the infrastructure deployment of each application that you want to host a front end for. It has both command line and tooling integrated into the development environment, such as BaaS or a web-based console to help you with deploying your applications. You can also deploy it as part of a MTA, a multi-target application. But the best news probably is that it is now available as part of the SAP BTP trial. So if you're curious about the application front-end service. Try it out today for free in the BTP trial.

[Mamikee] The latest Q2 2025 update for SAP BTP is now available, bringing exciting improvements across development, integration, analytics, and more. Some key highlights include application development and automation, which enhances tools for faster app building in the Cloud Foundry environment. Integration services, which updates to SAP's connectivity authorization and trust management and the audit log service, analytics and data management with new services and expanded support in data handling. This release continues SAP's BTP mission to unify database, AI, analytics, development automation, and integration seamlessly. Straight from SAP's foundation to today's cloud -native powerhouse. If you're building on BTP, these updates are designed to make your work smoother, smarter, and faster. You can read more in the description.

entry.title: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 1: Provisioning Joule Studio
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Introduction

This is the first part of a multi-part series designed to walk you through the end-to-end setup and usage of Joule Studio. In this part, we'll focus on provisioning—laying the foundation for a successful Joule Skill development journey.

Whether you're an architect, developer, or business process expert, this guide will help you correctly configure your SAP BTP environment, set up entitlements, and prepare your subaccount for secure and scalable development with Joule.

What is Joule Studio?

Joule Studio enhances the productivity and business impact of Joule, SAP's AI copilot. It is equipped with powerful capabilities designed to extend Joule’s intelligence to align with your organization’s specific processes, terminology, and needs.

Key Features:

  • Develop new Joule Skills for executing tailored, deterministic tasks aligned with business operations.
  • Manage and deploy updated skill versions to ensure continuous adaptability and improvement.
  • Define user access and permissions, ensuring the right teams can execute or administer the skills securely.
  • Seamlessly integrated with SAP Build, Joule Studio benefits from SAP's low-code/pro-code environment powered by generative AI.

SAP Joule Studio Architecture

 

Business Challenges and SAP's Solution

Business Challenges

  • Fragmented user experiences across enterprise applications.
  • Time-consuming manual processes, such as fetching business data.
  • Limited customization in out-of-the-box AI tools.
  • Technical complexity in onboarding automation tools.

SAP's Solution: Joule Studio with SAP Build

SAP addresses these challenges through:

  • Low-code development with SAP Build for quick customization.
  • Joule Booster to simplify provisioning and trust setup.
  • Joule Skills to extend the AI assistant with custom logic and backend integration.
  • BTP & IAS integration for secure, scalable access control.

 

Quotas

When using Joule Studio the following quotas apply.

A quota represents the numeric quantity that defines the maximum allowed consumption of a resource. In other words, how much of a service plan you're entitled to use.

You can find the quotas listed for Joule Studio below.

 

Action tasks

Connection timeout

1 minute

Time to establish the connection with the remote host.

 

Socket timeout

3 minutes

Maximum period between two data packets.

 

Total execution time

4 minutes

Total time an action task can execute.

 

Request body size

512 KB

 

 

Response content size

100 KB

 

Known Limitations

When using Joule Studio, note the following limitations:

  • The authorizations defined at environment level support users or user groups. Projects can be shared with a maximum of 10 user groups with execution or admin rights, or 5 users, and cannot be shared with a combination of user groups and users.
  • Deploying Joule skills to a shared environment in a production tenant can take up to 30 minutes.
  • It is possible to release and deploy a project in which no triggerable skills have been defined. However, this can lead to errors during the deployment.
  • When you use processes and automations from SAP Build Process Automation it is only possible for Joule Skills to start the processes or automations. Results from process and automations can not be integrated into the Joule skill flow.
  • If you type in values for Inputs or Outputs for your Joule skill and delete these manually, the value is missing but you can still release your project. The missing parameter can lead to errors when you run your Joule skill.
  • If you enter just a space, for example " ", in an input or output parameter, you can release your project but this can lead to errors during deployment.
  • When using a data type as input, if you use object binding to map to different fields, such as input and output parameters from other steps, this could lead to errors when you launch your Joule skill in Joule.
  • If you change permissions in a shared environment, you need to undeploy and redeploy the projects that have been deployed to the environment

Prerequisites

Before you begin, ensure the following:

  • The SAP Build - build-default plan is available in your Global Account.

 

  • The Joule entitlement is assigned in your Global Account.

 

  • Your IAS tenant is automatically discovered in the System Landscape of your BTP Global Account.
